8.9.17  10:33 am   Person that needs help with chords back. I need help with figuring out which chords are which, and chord progression.

     progression is a deceiving word. it doesn't mean anything. when someone says "chord progression" it just means a series of chords. it doesn't mean anything else

      Like how a Normal C major chord differs from those chords where you play C, F, A

     C, F, A is F major. to prove it, put the F on the bottom, then A above that, and C. looks just like a C chord in first position, except starting on F. you can also play a C chord as E, G, C. the notes in a triad (triad means a chord with 3 notes and no bass) can be in any order.

      instead and why its sounds better when I group it with some chords.

     why things sound 'good' is a subject you'll have to just explore through experimentation

      I
Also can't play bass clef and trouble clef at the same time very well at all.

     does that mean reading from both clefs, or do you just mean playing in both ranges at the same time?

     Thank you so much for the help! I'm having lots of fun reading the answers you give people on tips to play

8.8.17  9:50 pm   Hi, i was reading through the random questions (love that you added that ittle feature btw)... and i found one where you were talking about randomization process, and how you told yourself that you didn't HAVE to post the selected song, but you did have to record it fully and make it the best you possibly can (since choosing not to do the randomly selected song would defeat the purpose)... I'm just curious if this ever actually happened, that you made a complete, finished recording but ultimately decided not to post it? 

     no, it seems like that could never happen. that strategy is kind of a paradox. because if i finish it, that means i tried my best the whole way and finished it. which means i definitely can release it. but the reason the strategy was in place is so i don't start second guessing the song choice early on in production. it helps me suspend disbelief and just give it a try. it is a strange paradoxical strategy, and ultimately lost some validity after 'california' because at that point i firmly established a weekly song schedule and announced it publicly. and i wouldn't exactly have time to do an entire song and then abandon it. so when i chose the second song i pretty much knew i was locked into it, even though i might have wanted to abandon it

8.8.17  9:44 pm   I make music. In fact I've been making music for about a year. The way I've been doing it, though, has all been through sequencing. Recently I got a feeling like I didn't have enough knowledge of music theory or playing instruments in general to really make "good" music. (right now I play drum kit and tenor drums, so I know how rhythms work but I don't know how to form cool chords and stuff like that). Do you have any suggestions of any resources or things that I could do to learn some more theory or learn how to play some common chords and stuff?

     i don't know what every one really means by 'music theory,' it is a phrase that people use here in the questions over and over again, in a way that doesn't quite make any sense to me. but the best way to learn music, in my opinion, is by doing it and experiencing it, and experimenting. you can make many theories that way, and i don't know if that counts as music theory but it should, because they are theories you have about music

8.8.17  6:25 pm   I dont understand how people identify time signatures in almost all music (pop, rock, jazz, etc, etc). I play classical music,

     i think it's the same

     and i think the system is a bit different, but im not sure. Would you care explaining a little about that?

     step 1 is, find the beat. so as the music is going, see where you would tap your foot or nod your head, or wave your conducting wand. in most songs, this is pretty easy to find. of course you could always make crazy songs where you can't find it, but in Most songs you can find it. however, in most songs you can also do it twice as slow (or half as fast) if you want. in some songs, it is at just a certain tempo that you're almost not sure whether to tap the beat at one speed or twice as fast. this is ok, any piece of music can be written in multiple ways, you could set the tempo twice as fast and write all the notes as half the values and it would mean the same thing. but in most songs, it is reasonably clear where the foot-tap is. and i will go a step further to say that most music usually has these beats grouped together in groups of 2, 4, 8, etc. the way most music is written on paper is in groups of 4 beats, with bar lines dividing the bars (or 'measures'). most music uses 4 beats per bar. that being said it is really up to you to decide where the begining of the bars should be. but i think in most music there is a clear answer. to learn how to detect other time signatures besides 4/4, just start finding examples of them and then you will get better at hearing them. but when songs use 3-based time signatures, it can often be represented in multiple ways, many of which actually still heavily involve 4s. 2s, 3s, and 4s, are used all the time in music. it is very rare that music consistently uses a 5 or 7 pattern all the way through. usually when time signatures like 5 or 7 happen, it tends to be only once, and then goes back to 4. it is quite common for songs to need to add an extra beat or half a beat here and there, particularly at the end of the chorus or at the end of a section. this is accomplished by having 1 bar that is a different time signature. it is much more rare to have a song that entirely is based on a 5 pattern or a 7 pattern or another higher odd number. i'm not sure if that answers your question actually, but i think my most important point is that most music is in groups of 2, 4, and 8. and the way that is most commonly written on paper is with 4 beats per bar, and the time signature is called "4/4" (actually the first number is written above the second number but that's not easy to type here) the top or first number represents how many beats per bar. the bottom (or second) number is supposed to tell you what kind of a note gets the beat. so 4/4 should technically mean there are 4 beats in a bar and a 'quarter' note gets 1 beat. i realize there are holes in this system and many time signatures really can't be analyzed quite this way but that is the way the idea is supposed to work

8.8.17  3:30 pm   bill ive been pounding out kids songs like you wouldn't believe. it's very easy. why don't kids songs get to have the black keys? why are they special?

     there are 2 ways to be introduced to black keys. let's start by staying in the key of C. play the first 5 notes, up and down, c,d,e,f,g,f,e,d,c. this is part of the "key of C", specifically the key of C major. actually, it's all 7 notes all the way up. c,d,e,f,g,a,b,c. but let's just look at the first 5-- c,d,e,f,g. try JUST c, e, and g, all together at the same time. that's a chord. the name of that chord is C major. it is like your home chord in the key of C. ok great. now, plot twist, let's try a black note. instead of E, play the black note to the left of it instead (that note is called "E flat" which is written as E♭ or Eb if you don't have the flat symbol handy... whenever i type Eb it means "E flat") ..... so any time you would have played E, play Eb instead. so going up the first 5 notes of the C major scale but switching in Eb instead, you get C, D, Eb, F, G. and back down, G, F, Eb, D, C. you'll notice it has a darker sound, like "sad" basically. this is called C minor. try the chord, C, Eb, G. that is a "C minor" chord. the C minor scale going all the way up is usually C, D, Eb, F, G, Ab, Bb, C. but the top part of the scale has a few different options that come into play that we'll worry about once we start seeing them actually in songs. mess around with the notes in C minor a little bit, especially the first 5 notes. for a challenge, see if you can figure out "the ants go marching 1 by 1", which is a kids song in a minor key. hint: you will need to include notes all the way down to the G below your root C. hint: the word "march" will be on C, and the word "one" will be on Eb. let me know if you can figure this out

8.8.17  2:54 pm   I'm not good at writing songs, but I'm good at playing them, how do you write songs?

     you just have to start by experimenting. anything is possible, and the possibilities might be overwhelming at first. you can literally do anything. just start trying things and go from there

8.8.17  2:23 pm   so i've been playing around with learning songs by ear, and that's been working pretty well! but so far i've only been able to get pretty slow, uncomplicated ones. (e.g. most recently: peter gabriel's "here comes the flood" - the stripped down version, and schubert's "du bist die ruhe") i can almost always easily identify which notes to play until it gets up to like, 4 or more at one time. i have to sit there and go into hyperfocus and even then it takes me a minute. ive always thought i had a pretty good ear but maybe not - is this something i can develop with practice and experience? do you think it comes more naturally to some than to others?

     for the peter gabriel song, are you doing the vocal melody? for this one you will need to expand the range to include down to the G below your low C. i don't know if that helps. Also, I should mention, when you are learning these melodies, they will not necessarily be in the same key as the recording -- meaning, they will sound like the song if you play it by itself. but if you compare it with the recording, the whole thing may be higher or lower. also, not every song is possible to play all in 1 key. some times it borrows notes from other keys (for example, in C that means using the black notes). are you familiar with the the traditional alphabet song (also known as twinkle twinkle little star), or row, row, row your boat, or happy birthday? Try those. hint: happy birthday will actually require you to expand the range down to G, when playing it in the key of C. happy birthday would start on the low G note. the other 2 songs should start on C and only use the notes from C to C. let me know if this helps. all this is called "playing in the key of C", where the C note will feel like your home base. for example, if we were to play these songs in the key of D, all the notes would be up a little higher, and as an added twist you have to swap in a couple of black notes to get it to sound right. but you will learn that later

     as someone who wants to move there i'm concerned about how gentrification will affect rent prices. i always thought it's impossible to live there without a tech job and paycheck.

     you need a paycheck to live anywhere, but it does not need to be a tech job. keep in mind that brooklyn is much, much more than just williamsburg, greenpoint, etc. it's a hundred different places. it's just places and more places, as far as the eye can see. there's also queens (what's queens?) that's right, it's more places

     however i do know that you live there

     are you sure

     and don't have a tech job. is it hard to make ends meet living there?

     if you can find $11 an hour, i think you will be fine. as long as you are willing to live more than 30 minutes away from the city (manhattan) by train

8.8.17  10:55 am   You don't like Roman numerals(8.7.17  6:42 pm)

     that's not what i said, but i think in modern times not too many people understand them at first glance. they look like letters.

      :0 woah. What do you call a I,IV,V

     1, 4, 5 (by the way this is off the subject but if you are talking about a 4 bar chord sequence, in my opinion you really need to list all 4 bars, indicating which chord is doubled. such as 1, 1, 4, 5 or 1, 4, 5, 5. there is a huge difference depending on the timing, and if no timing is otherwise listed, just simply saying 1, 4, 5 (or I,IV,V) leaves me feeling still 100% left out of what is actually going on, with a 95% suspicion that it is actually referring to one of the two aforementioned 4-bar sequences, and being completely unable to determine which)

     or a I vi V IV? 

     1, 6-, 5, 4
